Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Thunderstorm Influences on Lightning and Atmospheric Chemistry in Oklahoma and North Texas during the Deep Convective Clouds and Chemistry (DC3) Project
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Deep Convective Clouds and Chemistry (DC3) field campaign to be conducted May-June 2012 is a multi-regional, multi-platform effort to determine the impact of deep midlatitude continental convective clouds and their intrinsic dynamical, microphysical, and electrification processes upon upper tropospheric composition and chemistry. This award will support collection and analysis of surface mesonet data in tandem with lightning mapping array (LMA) and in-situ balloon-borne measurements characterizing the electrical and microphysical behavior of thunderstorm systems within the Oklahoma-Texas subregion of DC3. This work will be done in coordination with airborne atmospheric chemistry measurements from by a specially instrumented NSF/NCAR GV high-altitude jet and NASA DC-8 platform. LMA data will be obtained from both an existing Oklahoma array and a planned west-Texas network. Mobile ballooning teams will work in close coordination with other NSF-supported investigators to obtain convective updraft profiles of electric fields, thermodynamics, airflow and videosonde measurements of hydrometeor size, shape, phase and number density and to interpret these measurements within the context of both fixed-based and mobile polarimetric radar observations.

The intellectual merit of this research derives from improved understanding of processes influencing lightning rates and structure (viz. channel lengths, structure and three-dimensional distribution) and storm-scale electric field polarity as a function of storm lifecycle and in relation to storm kinematic/microphysical properties, which will in-turn allow improved estimation lightning-induced NOx production and associated chemical transformations pivotal to DC3 program objectives. These measurements will also support improved numerical storm simulations through more accurate specification of storm environment and distribution of various hydrometeors throughout electrically active clouds. Broader impacts will accrue through both graduate and undergraduate student education within a field-project setting, via public outreach, by aiding operational forecasters in the interpretation of total lightning mapping data as anticipated from the GOES-R satellite, and ultimately through improved knowledge of the influence of deep atmospheric convection on the chemical composition of earth's atmosphere in the presence of natural and anthropogenic emissions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provided ground-based observations needed for the Oklahoma and Texas venue of the Deep Convective Clouds and Chemistry (DC3) field program, including detailed mapping of lightning inside storms; measurements of temperature, pressure, winds, and humidity at the ground and from balloons near storms; and measurements of the vertical distribution of electric fields and of the size, number concentration, and types of precipitation particles inside storms. These were added to the extensive suite of DC3 measurements of the chemistry, winds, and precipitation of storms provided by ground-based radars and multiple aircraft. With our observations we evaluated various hypotheses regarding relationships between lightning and other storm characteristics. Our project also provided critical information for other scientists to estimate the various chemicals storms either produced internally or transported from near ground to the upper troposphere.

Our new instrument, a precipitation imager, and novel image analysis software provided a unique capability to determine the true number and vertical distribution of raindrops, graupel, hail, snow, and small ice particles with a vertical resolution of 50 meters. We demonstrated that the particles detected by the imager agreed well with observations by local radars, but provided far more details.  For example, a flight through the periphery of the updraft and through the anvil of a supercell storm on which several DC3 research groups have focused observed several 1-2 cm diameter hailstones and large number concentrations of graupel, large irregular ice particles, and frozen particles too small to classify in video images. The distribution of particles varied considerably; one 50 meter layer of altitude could have a factor of 10-100 more particles than an adjoining 50 meter layer. This variability has important implications regarding charge generation and the influence of a storm’s charge distribution on lightning initiation and structure.

We also developed and used a greatly improved technique for estimating the type and number density of liquid and frozen particles from a continuous series of three-dimensional wind fields provided by two or more Doppler radars. The DLA estimates obtained for a supercell storm agreed well with the particles observed by the balloon-borne particle imager and with particles inferred from polarimetric radar. The DLA estimates of the evolving distribution of particles in a supercell storm were compared with the location, rate, and in-cloud structure of flashes observed by our lightning mapping system. The flash initiations and regions of charge inferred from lightning were related to graupel and small ice particles in ways that provided additional support for the theory that storms are electrified primarily by rebounding collisions between actively growing graupel and smaller ice particles. They also reinforced the more recent hypothesis that a sporadic minimum in lightning surrounded by a ring of lightning was caused by the interaction of the rotating updraft with particles being charged by this mechanism. Particles forming in the strong updraft core cascaded from near the top of the updraft and were swept around by the rotation around the core. Particles being charged in the periphery of the updraft lower down were swept around the upward spiraling winds.

Radar data for a small decaying storm and the north end of a large storm system were insufficient for applying the DLA technique, but the dominant type of precipitation in various regions was inferred from polarimetric radar. Again the initiation and structure of lightning were consistent with storms being electrified by collisions between graupel and small ice particles. We also investigated less well established effects that storms can have on lightning. For example, flash sizes tended to increase from very small flashes in the turbulent regions associated with large gradients in updraft speed near the periphery of updrafts to larger flash sizes in the smoother air flow farther from the updraft.

A more surprising finding was that a cluster of small flashes also occurred far from the updraft in the supercell storm. Small flashes were initiated high on the southern flank of the storm, tens of kilometers from the updraft core. As was true of most flashes, these small flashes were initiated on boundaries between a positive charge region and a negative charge region inferred from lightning. Variations in the wind field appeared to organize the charge there on relatively small distance scales.

Another unusual observation was that flashes in the northern section of the squall line we analyzed were initiated at much lower altitudes than we usually observe, probably because convection in the leading line was much weaker and shallower than in most Oklahoma thunderstorms. Furthermore, the majority of charge produced in the updraft was likely produced lower than usual because precipitation growth in upper regions occurred later and was of shorter duration than is usual in the evolution of stronger cells.

The new particle imager and DLA will be broadly useful for several basic and applied topics in thunderstorm research.
